item.title: Milvus Schema Detailed Guide - Field Types and Data Modeling
item.description:
Milvus Schema Learning Document

1. Understanding Schema Concept

1.1 What is Schema?

Schema is the metadata definition of a Collection, similar to table structure definition in relational databases.

Milvus Concept Relational Database Concept Description
Schema Table Schema Metadata defining data structure
Field Column Field/column definition
DataType Data Type Data types (VARCHAR, INT, FLOAT, etc.)
Primary Key Primary Key Primary key field
Vector Field - Milvus-specific vector field
Dynamic Field - Dynamic field, similar to MongoDB’s flexible Schema

1.2 Creating Schema 

from pymilvus import MilvusClient, DataType

# Create Schema
schema = client.create_schema(
 enable_dynamic_field=True # Enable dynamic fields
)

# Compare with MySQL
# CREATE TABLE products (
# ...
# );

2. Field Types Detailed

2.1 Field Classification 

Field Types
├── Scalar Fields
│ ├── String (VARCHAR)
│ ├── Numbers (INT8/INT16/INT32/INT64/FLOAT/DOUBLE/BOOL)
│ ├── JSON
│ ├── Arrays (ARRAY)
│ ├── Timestamp (TIMESTAMPTZ)
│ ├── Struct Arrays (ARRAY of STRUCT)
│ └── Geometry Fields (GEOMETRY)
└── Vector Fields
├── Dense Vectors (FLOAT_VECTOR/FLOAT16_VECTOR/BFLOAT16_VECTOR/INT8_VECTOR)
├── Sparse Vectors (SPARSE_FLOAT_VECTOR)
└── Binary Vectors (BINARY_VECTOR)

3. Primary Key Fields

3.1 Primary Key Type Comparison

Data Type Description Compare with MySQL
INT64 64-bit integer, recommended Similar to BIGINT AUTO_INCREMENT
VARCHAR Variable-length string Similar to VARCHAR(n) PRIMARY KEY

3.2 Auto ID vs Manual ID

Mode Description Use Cases Compare with MySQL
Auto ID Milvus automatically generates unique identifiers Most situations AUTO_INCREMENT
Manual ID User provides unique ID ID needs to be consistent with external systems Manually insert primary key values

3.3 Primary Key Field Examples 

# Auto ID Primary Key
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_id",
 datatype=DataType.INT64,
 is_primary=True, # Mark as primary key
 auto_id=True # Auto-generate ID
)

# Compare with MySQL
# product_id BIGINT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY

# Manual ID Primary Key (using string)
schema.add_field(
 field_name="sku_code",
 datatype=DataType.VARCHAR,
 max_length=50,
 is_primary=True,
 auto_id=False # Manual ID provision
)

# Compare with MySQL
# sku_code VARCHAR(50) PRIMARY KEY

4. Scalar Fields Detailed

4.1 String Fields (VARCHAR)

Attribute Description Range Compare with MySQL
datatype Data type DataType.VARCHAR VARCHAR
max_length Maximum length 1-65535 n in VARCHAR(n)
nullable Nullable True/False NULL/NOT NULL
default_value Default value String DEFAULT ‘value’ 
# String field example
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_name",
 datatype=DataType.VARCHAR,
 max_length=255,
 nullable=False,
 default_value="Unnamed Product"
)

# Compare with MySQL
# product_name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'Unnamed Product'

4.2 Numeric Fields

Milvus Type Description Range Compare with MySQL
BOOL Boolean value True/False BOOLEAN
INT8 8-bit integer -128 ~ 127 TINYINT
INT16 16-bit integer -32768 ~ 32767 SMALLINT
INT32 32-bit integer -2^31 ~ 2^31-1 INT
INT64 64-bit integer -2^63 ~ 2^63-1 BIGINT
FLOAT 32-bit float - FLOAT
DOUBLE 64-bit double - DOUBLE 
# Integer field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="stock_quantity",
 datatype=DataType.INT32,
 nullable=False,
 default_value=0
)

# Float field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_price",
 datatype=DataType.FLOAT,
 nullable=False
)

# Boolean field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="is_available",
 datatype=DataType.BOOL,
 default_value=True
)

# Compare with MySQL
# stock_quantity INT NOT NULL DEFAULT 0,
# product_price FLOAT NOT NULL,
# is_available BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE

4.3 JSON Fields

JSON Fields vs Dynamic Fields Comparison

Feature JSON Fields Dynamic Fields Compare with MySQL
Schema Definition Must be explicitly declared Hidden field $meta JSON column vs no equivalent concept
Use Cases Structured, known data Flexible, semi-structured data JSON column vs NoSQL features
Control User controls field names and structure System automatically managed -
Query Method metadata["key"] dynamic_key or $meta["key"] JSON_EXTRACT() 
# JSON field example
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_detail",
 datatype=DataType.JSON
)

# Insert data example
data = {
 "product_id": 1,
 "product_detail": {
 "brand": "Apple",
 "model": "iPhone 15",
 "specs": {
 "cpu": "A17 Pro",
 "ram": "8GB"
 }
 }
}

# Compare with MySQL
# product_detail JSON
# Query: SELECT JSON_EXTRACT(product_detail, '$.brand') FROM products;

JSON Indexing

JSON indexing suitable scenarios:

  1. Structured Schema with consistent, known keys
  2. Equality and range queries on specific JSON paths
  3. Need for precise control over indexed keys
  4. Efficient storage acceleration for target queries
# Create JSON index
index_params = MilvusClient.prepare_index_params()

index_params.add_index(
 field_name="product_detail", # JSON field name
 index_type="AUTOINDEX", # Must be AUTOINDEX or INVERTED
 index_name="idx_product_brand", # Index name
 params={
 "json_path": 'product_detail["brand"]', # Top-level key
 "json_cast_type": "VARCHAR" # Data type
 }
)

# Nested key indexing
index_params.add_index(
 field_name="product_detail",
 index_type="AUTOINDEX",
 index_name="idx_product_cpu",
 params={
 "json_path": 'product_detail["specs"]["cpu"]', # Nested key
 "json_cast_type": "VARCHAR"
 }
)

# Compare with MySQL 8.0+
# CREATE INDEX idx_product_brand ON products((JSON_EXTRACT(product_detail, '$.brand')));

JSON Shredding Optimization

JSON shredding accelerates queries by converting row-based storage to columnar storage.

Parameter Name Description Default Adjustment Suggestions
common.enabledJSONShredding Whether to enable JSON shredding false Set to true to activate feature
common.usingJSONShreddingForQuery Whether to use shredded data for acceleration true Set to false to restore when queries fail
queryNode.mmap.jsonShredding Whether to use mmap when loading true Adjust for special memory requirements
dataCoord.jsonShreddingMaxColumns Maximum shredded columns 1024 Increase when frequent keys exceed limit
dataCoord.jsonShreddingRatioThreshold Minimum occurrence rate threshold 0.3 Adjust shredding criteria 
# milvus.yaml configuration example
common:
 enabledJSONShredding: true
 usingJSONShreddingForQuery: true

queryNode:
 mmap:
 jsonShredding: true

dataCoord:
 jsonShreddingMaxColumns: 1024
 jsonShreddingRatioThreshold: 0.3

4.4 Array Fields (ARRAY) 

# String array
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_tags",
 datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
 element_type=DataType.VARCHAR,
 max_capacity=10, # Up to 10 elements
 max_length=50 # Each string up to 50 characters
)

# Integer array
schema.add_field(
 field_name="related_product_ids",
 datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
 element_type=DataType.INT64,
 max_capacity=20
)

# Insert data example
data = {
 "product_id": 1,
 "product_tags": ["Electronics", "Phone", "5G", "Smart"],
 "related_product_ids": [101, 102, 103]
}

# Compare with MySQL 8.0+
# product_tags JSON -- MySQL implements with JSON arrays
# Or use association tables for many-to-many relationships

4.5 Timestamp Fields (TIMESTAMPTZ)

TIMESTAMPTZ is timezone-aware timestamp type.

Feature Description Compare with MySQL
Input Format ISO 8601 strings (with timezone) TIMESTAMP
Internal Storage UTC normalized storage Depends on time_zone setting
Comparison Operations Unified UTC usage May be affected by timezone 
# Timestamp field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="created_at",
 datatype=DataType.TIMESTAMPTZ,
 nullable=False,
 default_value="2025-01-01T00:00:00+00:00"
)

# Insert data example
data = {
 "product_id": 1,
 "created_at": "2025-05-01T23:59:59+08:00" # Beijing time
}

# Compare with MySQL
# created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP

Timezone Management Levels

Level Parameter Scope Priority
Database timezone Default for all collections in database Lowest
Collection timezone Override database default timezone Medium
Query/Search timezone Temporary override for specific operation Highest 
# Database level timezone setting
client.alter_database_properties(
 "my_db",
 {"timezone": "Asia/Shanghai"}
)

# Collection level timezone setting (when creating collection)
client.create_collection(
 collection_name="products",
 schema=schema,
 properties={"timezone": "America/New_York"}
)

# Specify timezone temporarily during query
client.query(
 collection_name="products",
 filter="created_at > '2025-01-01T00:00:00+08:00'",
 timezone="Asia/Shanghai"
)

4.6 Struct Arrays (ARRAY of STRUCT)

Struct arrays are used to store complex nested data.

# Product reviews array example
struct_schema = client.create_struct_field_schema()
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="user_id",datatype=DataType.INT64)
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="rating",datatype=DataType.INT32)
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="comment",datatype=DataType.VARCHAR,max_length=500)
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="review_vector",datatype=DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR,dim=64)
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="timestamp",datatype=DataType.TIMESTAMPTZ)
schema.add_field(
 field_name="reviews",
 datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
 element_type=DataType.STRUCT,
 max_capacity=100,
 element_schema=struct_schema
)

# Insert data example
data = {
 "product_id": 1,
 "reviews": [
 {
 "user_id": 1001,
 "rating": 5,
 "comment": "Very good!",
 "review_vector": [0.1, 0.2, ...], # 64-dimensional vector
 "timestamp": "2025-05-01T10:00:00+08:00"
 },
 {
 "user_id": 1002,
 "rating": 4,
 "comment": "Pretty good",
 "review_vector": [0.3, 0.4, ...],
 "timestamp": "2025-05-02T15:30:00+08:00"
 }
 ]
}

# Compare with MySQL
# Need to create association table reviews
# CREATE TABLE reviews (
# review_id BIGINT PRIMARY KEY,
# product_id BIGINT,
# user_id BIGINT,
# rating INT,
# comment VARCHAR(500),
# timestamp TIMESTAMP,
# FOREIGN KEY (product_id) REFERENCES products(product_id)
# );

4.7 Geometry Fields (GEOMETRY)

Used to store geographic location and coordinate information.

# Geometry field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="store_location",
 datatype=DataType.GEOMETRY,
 default_value="POINT(0 0)"
)

# Insert data example
data = {
 "product_id": 1,
 "store_location": "POINT(116.4074 39.9042)" # Tiananmen Square coordinates, Beijing
}

# Compare with MySQL
# store_location POINT NOT NULL
# Or use PostGIS extension GEOMETRY type

5. Vector Fields Detailed

5.1 Vector Type Comparison

Milvus Type Description Use Cases Storage Size
FLOAT_VECTOR 32-bit float vector High-precision semantic search 4 bytes/dim
FLOAT16_VECTOR 16-bit half-precision float Deep learning, GPU computing 2 bytes/dim
BFLOAT16_VECTOR 16-bit brain float Large-scale image retrieval 2 bytes/dim
INT8_VECTOR 8-bit integer vector Quantized models, fast inference 1 byte/dim
SPARSE_FLOAT_VECTOR Sparse float vector Full-text search, term matching Variable
BINARY_VECTOR Binary vector Resource-constrained scenarios 1 bit/dim

5.2 Dense Vector Examples 

# FLOAT_VECTOR - Standard dense vector
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_embedding",
 datatype=DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR,
 dim=128 # 128-dimensional vector
)

# FLOAT16_VECTOR - Half-precision vector
schema.add_field(
 field_name="image_embedding",
 datatype=DataType.FLOAT16_VECTOR,
 dim=512
)

# INT8_VECTOR - Quantized vector
schema.add_field(
 field_name="text_embedding_quantized",
 datatype=DataType.INT8_VECTOR,
 dim=256
)

# Insert data example
import numpy as np

data = {
 "product_id": 1,
 "product_embedding": np.random.rand(128).tolist(), # 128-dim float vector
 "image_embedding": np.random.rand(512).astype(np.float16).tolist(),
 "text_embedding_quantized": np.random.randint(-128, 127, 256).tolist()
}

# MySQL has no equivalent type, needs to be stored as BLOB or JSON

5.3 Sparse Vector Examples 

# Sparse vector field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="keyword_vector",
 datatype=DataType.SPARSE_FLOAT_VECTOR
)

# Insert data example (sparse vector format)
data = {
 "product_id": 1,
 "keyword_vector": {
 10: 0.5, # Index 10 value is 0.5
 25: 0.8, # Index 25 value is 0.8
 100: 0.3 # Index 100 value is 0.3
 }
}

6. Dynamic Fields

6.1 Dynamic Field Concept

Dynamic fields allow inserting fields not defined in Schema, which are automatically stored in the hidden $meta JSON field.

# Enable dynamic fields
schema = client.create_schema(
 enable_dynamic_field=True # Enable dynamic fields
)

# Define basic fields
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_id",
 datatype=DataType.INT64,
 is_primary=True,
 auto_id=True
)

schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_vector",
 datatype=DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR,
 dim=128
)

# Can include undefined fields when inserting data
data = {
 "product_id": 1,
 "product_vector": [0.1, 0.2, ...],
 "name": "iPhone 15", # Not defined in Schema
 "category": "Electronics", # Not defined in Schema
 "price": 999.99 # Not defined in Schema
}

# Milvus internally stores as:
# {
# "product_id": 1,
# "product_vector": [0.1, 0.2, ...],
# "$meta": {
# "name": "iPhone 15",
# "category": "Electronics",
# "price": 999.99
# }
# }

6.2 Supported Types for Dynamic Fields

Type Milvus DataType Compare with MongoDB
String VARCHAR String
Integer INT8, INT32, INT64 Int32, Int64
Float FLOAT, DOUBLE Double
Boolean BOOL Boolean
Array ARRAY Array
JSON Object JSON Object

6.3 Querying Dynamic Fields 

# Direct field name query
results = client.query(
 collection_name="products",
 filter='name == "iPhone 15"', # Directly use dynamic field name
 output_fields=["product_id", "name", "category", "price"]
)

# Or query through $meta
results = client.query(
 collection_name="products",
 filter='$meta["category"] == "Electronics"',
 output_fields=["product_id", "$meta"]
)

# Compare with MongoDB
# db.products.find({"name": "iPhone 15"})

7. Complete Schema Example 

from pymilvus import MilvusClient, DataType

# Connect client
client = MilvusClient(uri="http://localhost:19530", token="root:Milvus")

# Create Schema
schema = client.create_schema(
 enable_dynamic_field=True # Enable dynamic fields
)

# 1. Primary key field (Auto ID)
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_id",
 datatype=DataType.INT64,
 is_primary=True,
 auto_id=True
)

# 2. String field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_name",
 datatype=DataType.VARCHAR,
 max_length=255
)

# 3. Numeric field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_price",
 datatype=DataType.FLOAT
)

# 4. JSON field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_detail",
 datatype=DataType.JSON
)

# 5. Array field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_tags",
 datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
 element_type=DataType.VARCHAR,
 max_capacity=10,
 max_length=50
)

# 6. Timestamp field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="created_at",
 datatype=DataType.TIMESTAMPTZ
)

# 7. Struct array
struct_schema = client.create_struct_field_schema()
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="user_id",datatype=DataType.INT64)
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="rating",datatype=DataType.INT32)
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="comment",datatype=DataType.VARCHAR,max_length=500)
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="review_vector",datatype=DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR,dim=64)
struct_schema.add_field(field_name="timestamp",datatype=DataType.TIMESTAMPTZ)
schema.add_field(
 field_name="reviews",
 datatype=DataType.ARRAY,
 element_type=DataType.STRUCT,
 max_capacity=100,
 element_schema=struct_schema
)

# 8. Geometry field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="store_location",
 datatype=DataType.GEOMETRY,
 default_value="POINT(0 0)"
)

# 9. Dense vector field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="product_embedding",
 datatype=DataType.FLOAT_VECTOR,
 dim=128
)

# 10. Sparse vector field
schema.add_field(
 field_name="keyword_vector",
 datatype=DataType.SPARSE_FLOAT_VECTOR
)

print("✅ Schema creation completed")

8. Schema vs MySQL Comparison Summary

Operation Milvus MySQL
Create Schema client.create_schema() CREATE TABLE
Add Field schema.add_field() ALTER TABLE ADD COLUMN
Primary Key Definition is_primary=True PRIMARY KEY
Auto ID auto_id=True AUTO_INCREMENT
Nullable Field nullable=True NULL
Default Value default_value=value DEFAULT value
Vector Fields FLOAT_VECTOR etc. No equivalent type
Dynamic Fields enable_dynamic_field=True None (need JSON or NoSQL)

9. Best Practices

9.1 Field Naming Conventions 

# ✅ Recommended
"product_id"
"user_name"
"created_at"

# ❌ Avoid
"Product-ID" # Avoid hyphens
"用户名" # Avoid non-ASCII
"field name" # Avoid spaces

9.2 Vector Dimension Selection

Scenario Recommended Dimensions Model Examples
Text Embedding 384-768 sentence-transformers
Image Embedding 512-2048 ResNet, CLIP
Multimodal 512-1024 CLIP, ALIGN

9.3 Index Strategy 

# Create index for vector fields
index_params = MilvusClient.prepare_index_params()

# HNSW index (recommended for high-precision search)
index_params.add_index(
 field_name="product_embedding",
 index_type="HNSW",
 metric_type="COSINE",
 params={"M": 16, "efConstruction": 256}
)

# IVF_FLAT index (suitable for large-scale data)
index_params.add_index(
 field_name="image_embedding",
 index_type="IVF_FLAT",
 metric_type="L2",
 params={"nlist": 1024}
)

10. Key Points Summary

  1. Schema Flexibility: Milvus supports dynamic fields, more flexible than traditional relational databases
  2. Native Vector Support: Vector fields are first-class citizens, no extra conversion needed
  3. Rich Types: Supports JSON, arrays, structs and other complex types
  4. Timezone Awareness: TIMESTAMPTZ provides native timezone support
  5. Index Optimization: JSON shredding, vector indexing and other optimization techniques
  6. NoSQL Integration: Dynamic fields similar to MongoDB, but retain Schema constraint advantages

item.title: Complete Guide to Installing Milvus Standalone Mode and Common Problem Solutions
item.description:
Introduction

Milvus is an open-source vector database designed specifically for handling large-scale vector data, supporting vector similarity search, real-time queries, and other features. The Standalone mode is Milvus’s single-machine embedded deployment method, suitable for learning, testing, and small-scale applications. It runs using Docker containers with embedded etcd as metadata storage, requiring no external dependencies.

During the actual installation process, I encountered multiple issues including non-existent image tags, network connection refusals, container permission issues causing startup failures (Exited 134), and scripts getting stuck in waiting states. This article is based on real installation experience on a VMware Ubuntu virtual machine on February 24, 2026, providing complete steps and systematically summarizing problems and solutions. The host machine configuration is Intel Core i9-12900H + 16 GB RAM.

Environment Preparation

System Requirements

  • Ubuntu 20.04 or higher version (22.04 LTS recommended)
  • Docker 20.10 or higher version
  • Minimum VM configuration recommendation: 8-12 GB RAM, 4-8 vCPU (recommended 1 processor × 6-8 cores)
  • Network: Domestic mirror accelerator recommended

Configure Docker Image Accelerator

Edit /etc/docker/daemon.json:

{
 "registry-mirrors": [
 "https://docker.xuanyuan.me",
 "https://mirror.ccs.tencentyun.com",
 "https://hub-mirror.c.163.com",
 "https://docker.mirrors.ustc.edu.cn"
 ]
}

Restart Docker:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl restart docker

Verify accelerator configuration:

sudo docker info | grep -A 10 "Registry Mirrors"

Installation Steps

1. Download Official Standalone Embedded Startup Script 

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/milvus-io/milvus/master/scripts/standalone_embed.sh
chmod +x standalone_embed.sh

2. Modify Image Tag (v2.6.11 Not Pushed, Use Latest Available Build from Master Branch)

Edit standalone_embed.sh, find the image line in the docker run command, change:

milvusdb/milvus:v2.6.11 \

to:

milvusdb/milvus:master-20260224-091b147e-amd64 \

or a more stable previous day version:

milvusdb/milvus:master-20260223-49bf0b63-amd64 \

Save the file.

3. Create and Set Data Directory Permissions (Most Critical Step, Avoid Permission Denial) 

# Delete old directory (prevent residual permission errors)
rm -rf ./volumes/milvus

# Create new directory
mkdir -p ./volumes/milvus

# Set owner and permissions (ensure non-root user in container can write)
sudo chown -R $USER:$USER ./volumes/milvus
chmod -R 775 ./volumes/milvus

# Verify permissions (should show drwxrwxr-x ai-stu ai-stu)
ls -ld ./volumes/milvus

4. Start Milvus 

bash standalone_embed.sh start

5. Verify Success

Wait for script output “Start successfully.”

Check container status:

sudo docker ps

Should show Up ... (healthy)

Test health endpoint:

curl http://localhost:19530/healthz

Should return "ok"

Common Problems Summary and Solutions

Problem 1: Image Pull Failure (not found / connection refused)

Phenomenon:

  • Unable to find image ... not found or dial tcp ... connection refused

Cause:

  • v2.6.11 tag not yet pushed to Docker Hub
  • Domestic network access to registry-1.docker.io is restricted

Solutions:

  1. Use stable version tags: Switch to released stable versions like v2.6.10 
    sudo docker run -d \
 --name milvus-standalone \
 --gpus all \
 -e ETCD_USE_EMBED=true \
 -e COMMON_STORAGETYPE=local \
 -p 19530:19530 \
 -v ${DOCKER_VOLUME_DIRECTORY:-.}/volumes/milvus:/var/lib/milvus \
 milvusdb/milvus:v2.6.10
  2. Configure domestic accelerators (Xuanyuan, Alibaba Cloud, NetEase, etc.)
  3. Offline transfer method: pull + save on accessible network machine:
docker pull milvusdb/milvus:master-20260224-091b147e-amd64
docker save -o milvus.tar milvusdb/milvus:master-20260224-091b147e-amd64
gzip milvus.tar

Load after transferring to server:

gunzip milvus.tar.gz
sudo docker load -i milvus.tar

Problem 2: Container Exits Immediately After Startup (Exited 134)

Phenomenon:

  • sudo docker ps -a shows Exited (134)

Cause:

  • SIGABRT signal, internal process abort
  • Usually caused by permission denial, initialization failure, or insufficient memory

Solutions:

  1. Check logs: 
    sudo docker logs milvus-standalone --tail 100
  2. Increase VM memory to 8-12 GB
  3. Clean and reset permissions (see step 3)
  4. Try more stable tags (such as master-20260223-49bf0b63-amd64)

Problem 3: Permission Denied (mkdir /var/lib/milvus/data/: permission denied)

Phenomenon:

  • Logs show [FATAL] ... permission denied and panic

Cause:

  • Host ./volumes/milvus directory lacks sufficient permissions
  • Non-root user in container cannot create subdirectories

Solutions:

  1. Must delete old directory first: 
    rm -rf ./volumes/milvus
  2. Recreate and set permissions (step 3)
  3. Recommend using 775 permissions to ensure group writability

Problem 4: Script Stuck at “Wait for Milvus Starting…”

Phenomenon:

  • Script shows no output for extended period

Cause:

  • Container hasn’t reached healthy state (crashed or health check failed)

Solutions:

  1. Check status in new terminal: 
    sudo docker ps -a
  2. View real-time logs: 
    sudo docker logs -f milvus-standalone
  3. Manually test health endpoint: 
    curl http://localhost:19530/healthz
  4. Clean data volumes and retry

item.title: Complete Guide to Claude Code Skills
item.description:
Personal study notes

Chapter 1: What are Skills

1.1 Introduction to Skills

Skills are an extension system for Claude Code, similar to installing “skill packs” for Claude.

Simple Understanding:

  • Like mobile apps: you can install different apps on your phone to achieve different functions
  • Skills are “functional plugins” installed for Claude
  • Each Skill teaches Claude a new capability

Examples:

  • Install docx skill → Claude can create and edit Word documents
  • Install pdf skill → Claude can process PDF files
  • Install mysql-manager skill → Claude can operate databases

1.2 Types of Skills

Official Skills (Provided by Anthropic)

  • Developed and maintained by Claude’s official team
  • Guaranteed quality and stable functionality
  • Free to use
  • Examples: docx, pdf, pptx, xlsx, etc.

Community Skills (Third-party Development)

  • Contributed by community developers
  • Diverse functionalities
  • Quality needs to be evaluated independently

Custom Skills (Created by You)

  • Customized according to your needs
  • Fully controllable
  • This tutorial will teach you how to create them

1.3 Why Use Skills

Without Skills:

You: Help me create a Word document
Claude: Sorry, I cannot directly create Word documents

With Skills:

You: Help me create a Word document
Claude: OK! (Automatically uses docx skill to create document)

Advantages of Skills:

  1. ✅ Extend Claude’s capabilities
  2. ✅ Automate repetitive tasks
  3. ✅ Improve work efficiency
  4. ✅ Can customize exclusive functions

1.4 How Skills Work 

Your request → Claude analyzes → Select appropriate Skill → Execute operation → Return results

Example Process:

  1. You say: “Create a Word document”
  2. Claude identifies that document processing is needed
  3. Claude calls the docx skill
  4. docx skill executes document creation code
  5. Returns the created document

Chapter 2: Environment Preparation

2.1 Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have installed:

Required Software

1. Claude Code CLI

  • This is Claude’s command-line tool
  • If you can run Claude Code, it means you’ve already installed it
  • Check method: 
    claude --version

2. Node.js (Required for some skills)

  • Version requirement: 14.0 or higher
  • Check installation: 
    node --version
npm --version
  • If not installed, visit: https://nodejs.org/
  • Download LTS (Long Term Support) version

3. Git (Optional, for cloning official repository)

  • Check installation: 
    git --version
  • If not installed, visit: https://git-scm.com/

2.2 Understanding File Locations

Important Directory Structure:

Your user directory/
├── .claude/ # Claude configuration directory
│ ├── skills/ # Custom skills storage location
│ │ └── mysql-manager/ # Example: custom skill
│ │ ├── SKILL.md # Skill definition file
│ │ ├── config.json # Configuration file
│ │ ├── mysql-tool.js # Tool script
│ │ └── README.md # Documentation
│ ├── plugins/ # Plugins directory
│ │ └── marketplaces/ # Skills marketplace
│ │ └── anthropic-agent-skills/
│ │ └── skills/ # Official skills
│ │ ├── docx/
│ │ ├── pdf/
│ │ └── ...
│ └── config.json # Global configuration file

Paths on Different Operating Systems:

Windows:

  • User directory: C:\Users\YourUsername\
  • Claude directory: C:\Users\YourUsername\.claude\
  • View method: 
    echo %USERPROFILE%\.claude

Mac:

  • User directory: /Users/YourUsername/
  • Claude directory: /Users/YourUsername/.claude/
  • View method: 
    echo ~/.claude

Linux:

  • User directory: /home/YourUsername/
  • Claude directory: /home/YourUsername/.claude/
  • View method: 
    echo ~/.claude

Chapter 4: Using Skills

4.1 Three Ways to Use Skills

Method 1: Natural Language (Recommended for Beginners)

Directly describe your needs in everyday language, Claude will automatically select the appropriate skill.

Examples:

Create a Word document
Process this PDF file
Design a login page
Query database

Advantages:

  • Simplest, no need to remember skill names
  • Claude automatically determines which skill to use
  • Suitable for daily use

Disadvantages:

  • Sometimes Claude might choose the wrong skill
  • Not precise enough

Method 2: Explicitly Specify Skill

If you know which skill to use, you can specify it explicitly.

Examples:

Use docx skill to create report
Use pdf skill to extract text
Use mysql-manager to query data

Advantages:

  • More precise
  • Avoids Claude choosing wrong skill
  • Suitable for repetitive tasks

Disadvantages:

  • Need to remember skill names

Method 3: Direct Command Call (Advanced Users)

For custom skills, can call commands directly.

Examples:

cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
node mysql-tool.js list-databases

Advantages:

  • Fastest
  • Full control
  • Suitable for scripting

Disadvantages:

  • Need command-line knowledge
  • Need to know specific commands

4.3 Skills Usage Tips

Tip 1: Provide Detailed Information

Poor Example:

Create a document

Good Example:

Create a Word document, filename report.docx, including:
- Title: Project Report
- Three chapters: Background, Solution, Conclusion
- Each chapter contains 2-3 paragraphs
- Save to current directory
  • Clear and specific
  • Claude knows exactly what to do

Tip 2: Operate Step by Step

For complex tasks, proceed step by step:

Step 1: First help me check what tables are in the database
(wait for results)
Step 2: Query the structure of users table
(wait for results)

Why step by step?

  • Each step can confirm results

Chapter 6: Practical Case - MySQL Database Management Skill

This chapter will teach you how to create a powerful MySQL database management Skill through a complete practical case.

6.1 Requirements Analysis

Goal: Create a Skill to manage MySQL databases

Functional Requirements:

  1. Database management (create, delete, list)
  2. Table management (create, delete, view structure)
  3. Data querying (SELECT, statistics)
  4. Data operations (insert, update, delete)
  5. Import/export (CSV, JSON, SQL)
  6. Backup and recovery
  7. User management
  8. Performance analysis

Technology Selection:

  • Node.js + mysql2 library
  • Configuration file stores connection information
  • Command-line tool implements various operations

6.2 Creating Skill Structure

Step 1: Create Directory

mkdir -p ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager

Step 2: Initialize npm Project

npm init -y
npm install mysql2

6.3 Creating Configuration File

config.json:

{
 "host": "localhost",
 "port": 3306,
 "user": "root",
 "password": "root",
 "database": "",
 "charset": "utf8mb4",
 "connectionLimit": 10,
 "connectTimeout": 10000,
 "backupPath": "~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager/backups"
}

Configuration Explanation:

  • host: Database server address
  • port: Port number (default 3306)
  • user: Database username
  • password: Database password
  • database: Default database (can be empty)
  • backupPath: Backup file storage path

Security Note:

# Set configuration file permissions (owner read/write only)
chmod 600 config.json

6.4 Creating Core Tool Script

mysql-tool.js (Core functionality implementation):

#!/usr/bin/env node

const mysql = require('mysql2/promise');
const fs = require('fs').promises;
const path = require('path');

// Load configuration
async function loadConfig() {
 const configPath = path.join(__dirname, 'config.json');
 const configData = await fs.readFile(configPath, 'utf8');
 return JSON.parse(configData);
}

// Create database connection
async function createConnection(dbName = null) {
 const config = await loadConfig();
 if (dbName) {
 config.database = dbName;
 }
 return await mysql.createConnection(config);
}

// List all databases
async function listDatabases() {
 const conn = await createConnection();
 const [rows] = await conn.execute('SHOW DATABASES');
 await conn.end();
 return rows.map(row => row.Database);
}

// List all tables
async function listTables(dbName) {
 const conn = await createConnection(dbName);
 const [rows] = await conn.execute('SHOW TABLES');
 await conn.end();
 return rows.map(row => Object.values(row)[0]);
}

// Query data
async function selectAll(dbName, tableName, limit = 100) {
 const conn = await createConnection(dbName);
 const [rows] = await conn.execute(
 `SELECT * FROM \`${tableName}\` LIMIT ?`,
 [limit]
 );
 await conn.end();
 return rows;
}

// Main function
async function main() {
 const args = process.argv.slice(2);
 const command = args[0];

 try {
 let result;

 switch (command) {
 case 'list-databases':
 result = await listDatabases();
 break;
 case 'list-tables':
 result = await listTables(args[1]);
 break;
 case 'select-all':
 result = await selectAll(args[1], args[2], parseInt(args[3] || 100));
 break;
 default:
 console.error('Unknown command:', command);
 process.exit(1);
 }

 console.log(JSON.stringify(result, null, 2));
 } catch (error) {
 console.error('Error:', error.message);
 process.exit(1);
 }
}

if (require.main === module) {
 main();
}

Set Execution Permissions:

chmod +x mysql-tool.js

6.5 Creating SKILL.md 

---
name: mysql-manager
description: Comprehensive MySQL database management tool. Supports connecting to databases, executing queries, data import/export, backup/restore, table structure management, etc. Requires configuration of database connection information before use.
---

# MySQL Database Management Skill

This skill provides comprehensive MySQL database operation functions.

## Configuration

Database connection information is stored in `~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager/config.json`.

Default configuration:
```json
{
 "host": "localhost",
 "port": 3306,
 "user": "root",
 "password": "root"
}

Supported Operations

Database Management

  • List all databases
  • Create database
  • Delete database
  • View database size

Table Management

  • List all tables
  • Create table
  • Delete table
  • View table structure

Data Query

  • SELECT queries
  • Conditional queries
  • Statistical queries

Data Operations

  • Insert data
  • Update data
  • Delete data

Import/Export

  • Export to CSV
  • Export to JSON
  • Export to SQL
  • Import from SQL

Backup and Recovery

  • Backup database
  • Restore database

Usage Examples 

Use mysql-manager to list all databases
Use mysql-manager to query data from users table
Use mysql-manager to backup mydb database

Security Considerations

  1. Configuration file contains sensitive information, ensure permissions are set correctly
  2. Use read-only users for queries in production environments
  3. Confirm before deletion operations
  4. Regularly backup important data

6.8 Extending Functions

Adding More Commands:

  1. Create Database:
async function createDatabase(dbName) {
 const conn = await createConnection();
 await conn.execute(`CREATE DATABASE IF NOT EXISTS \`${dbName}\``);
 await conn.end();
 return `Database ${dbName} created successfully`;
}
  1. Export to CSV:
async function exportToCSV(dbName, tableName, outputPath) {
 const conn = await createConnection(dbName);
 const [rows] = await conn.execute(`SELECT * FROM \`${tableName}\``);
 await conn.end();

 const headers = Object.keys(rows[0]).join(',');
 const csvRows = rows.map(row =>
 Object.values(row).map(val =>
 typeof val === 'string' ? `"${val}"` : val
 ).join(',')
 );

 const csv = [headers, ...csvRows].join('\n');
 await fs.writeFile(outputPath, csv, 'utf8');

 return `Export successful: ${outputPath}`;
}
  1. Backup Database:
async function backupDatabase(dbName, outputPath) {
 const cmd = `mysqldump -u ${config.user} -p${config.password} ${dbName} > "${outputPath}"`;
 await execPromise(cmd);
 return `Backup successful: ${outputPath}`;
}

Chapter 7: Common Problems and Solutions

7.1 Installation Issues

Problem 1: Cannot Add Official Marketplace

Error Message:

Failed to add marketplace

Possible Causes:

  • Network connection issues
  • Cannot access GitHub
  • Proxy configuration issues

Solutions:

  1. Check network connection:
ping github.com
  1. Configure Git proxy (if in China):
git config --global http.proxy http://proxy.example.com:8080
git config --global https.proxy https://proxy.example.com:8080
  1. Use VPN or proxy

Problem 2: Skills Don’t Show After Installation

Symptoms:

  • Installation successful but Claude doesn’t see skills
  • Asking “What skills do you have?” shows nothing

Solutions:

  1. Restart Claude Code (most common cause):
# Exit
exit

# Restart
claude-code
  1. Check Installation Location:
ls ~/.claude/plugins/cache/
  1. Reinstall:
/plugin uninstall example-skills
/plugin install example-skills@anthropic-agent-skills

Problem 3: Dependency Installation Failed

Error Message:

npm ERR! Cannot find module 'mysql2'

Solutions:

  1. Enter skill directory:
cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
  1. Install dependencies:
npm install mysql2
  1. If still failing, clear cache:
npm cache clean --force
npm install

7.2 Usage Issues

Problem 4: Skill Execution Failed

Error Message:

Error: Command failed

Troubleshooting Steps:

  1. Check if command is correct:
# Manually test command
cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
node mysql-tool.js list-databases

  1. View error details: Claude usually shows detailed error information

  2. Check permissions:

# Ensure script has execution permissions
chmod +x mysql-tool.js
  1. Check configuration file:
# Validate JSON format
cat config.json | python -m json.tool

Problem 5: Claude Chose Wrong Skill

Symptoms:

  • You want to use skill A, but Claude used skill B

Solutions:

  1. Explicitly specify skill:
Use docx skill to create document (instead of "create document")
  1. Provide more detailed description:
Use mysql-manager skill to query database
  1. Check SKILL.md description: Ensure description is clear and won’t confuse with other skills

Problem 6: Configuration File Not Found

Error Message:

Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory

Solutions:

  1. Check if file exists:
ls ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager/config.json
  1. Check path correctness: Use absolute path in script:
const configPath = path.join(__dirname, 'config.json');
  1. Create configuration file:
cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
cat > config.json << EOF
{
 "host": "localhost",
 "port": 3306
}
EOF

7.3 Database Issues

Problem 7: Cannot Connect to Database

Error Messages:

Error: connect ECONNREFUSED
Error: Access denied for user

Solutions:

  1. Check if MySQL service is running:
# Windows
sc query MySQL

# Mac
brew services list | grep mysql

# Linux
systemctl status mysql
  1. Check connection information:
# Test connection
mysql -h localhost -u root -p
  1. Check firewall:
# Linux
sudo ufw status

# Windows
netsh advfirewall show allprofiles
  1. Check user permissions:
-- Execute in MySQL
SHOW GRANTS FOR 'root'@'localhost';

Problem 8: Backup Failed

Error Message:

mysqldump: command not found

Solutions:

  1. Install MySQL client tools:
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get install mysql-client

# Mac
brew install mysql-client

# Windows
# Download MySQL Installer
  1. Add to PATH (Windows):
Add C:\Program Files\MySQL\MySQL Server 8.0\bin to system PATH
  1. Use full path:
const mysqldumpPath = 'C:\\Program Files\\MySQL\\MySQL Server 8.0\\bin\\mysqldump.exe';

7.4 Performance Issues

Problem 9: Queries Are Slow

Symptoms:

  • Querying large tables responds slowly
  • Claude takes long time to respond

Solutions:

  1. Limit query count:
// Default limit 100 rows
async function selectAll(dbName, tableName, limit = 100) {
 // ...
}
  1. Add indexes:
CREATE INDEX idx_name ON users(name);
  1. Use pagination:
async function selectPage(dbName, tableName, page, pageSize) {
 const offset = (page - 1) * pageSize;
 const [rows] = await conn.execute(
 `SELECT * FROM \`${tableName}\` LIMIT ? OFFSET ?`,
 [pageSize, offset]
 );
 return rows;
}

Problem 10: High Memory Usage

Symptoms:

  • Node.js process occupies large memory
  • System becomes slow

Solutions:

  1. Use streaming processing:
const stream = conn.query(`SELECT * FROM large_table`).stream();
stream.on('data', (row) => {
 // Process each row
});
  1. Close connections promptly:
try {
 // Operations
} finally {
 await conn.end();
}
  1. Limit connection pool size:
{
 "connectionLimit": 5
}

7.5 Document Issues

npm install -g docx

npm list

# Run script
node script.js

# Debug mode
node --inspect script.js

E. Git Commands 

# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/anthropics/skills.git

# View status
git status

# Pull updates
git pull

# View logs
git log --oneline -10

F. MySQL Commands 

# Connect to database
mysql -h localhost -u root -p

# Export database
mysqldump -u root -p mydb > backup.sql

# Import database
mysql -u root -p mydb < backup.sql

# View processes
mysqladmin -u root -p processlist

G. Common Skill Command Templates

MySQL Manager 

# List databases
node mysql-tool.js list-databases

# List tables
node mysql-tool.js list-tables mydb

# Query data
node mysql-tool.js select-all mydb users 10

# Export CSV
node mysql-tool.js export-csv mydb users output.csv

# Backup
node mysql-tool.js backup mydb backup.sql

File Statistics 

# Statistics current directory
node file-stats.js .

# Statistics specified directory
node file-stats.js /path/to/directory

Appendix B: Configuration File Templates

1. SKILL.md Template 

---
name: skill-name
description: Detailed description of this skill's functions and usage scenarios
---

# Skill Name

Brief introduction.

## Functions

- Function 1
- Function 2
- Function 3

## Usage

Detailed usage instructions...

## Examples

Use skill-name to do something


## Configuration
If configuration is needed, explain here.
## Dependencies
List required dependencies.
## Notes
Important notes.

2. config.json Template 

{
 "host": "localhost",
 "port": 3306,
 "user": "username",
 "password": "password",
 "database": "dbname",
 "options": {
 "key": "value"
 }
}

3. package.json Template 

{
 "name": "skill-name",
 "version": "1.0.0",
 "description": "Skill description",
 "main": "index.js",
 "scripts": {
 "test": "node test.js"
 },
 "dependencies": {
 "mysql2": "^3.0.0"
 },
 "author": "Your Name",
 "license": "MIT"
}

4. README.md Template 

# Skill Name

Brief description.

## Installation

```bash
cd ~/.claude/skills/skill-name
npm install

Configuration

Edit config.json:

{
 "key": "value"
}

Usage

Command Line 

node tool.js command

Claude Code 

Use skill-name to do something

Command Reference

Command Description Example
command1 Description node tool.js command1
command2 Description node tool.js command2

item.title: Properties to YAML Conversion Tool
item.description:
Properties to YAML Conversion Tool User Manual

📋 Overview

This is a powerful Python script tool for converting Java .properties configuration files to YAML format. The tool not only supports basic format conversion, but also features intelligent comment preservation, type inference, and structure maintenance functions.

📜 Script 

#!/usr/bin/env python3
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""
Properties文件转YAML文件工具（优化版）
优化点：
1. 使用普通dict替代OrderedDict（Python 3.7+保持插入顺序）
2. 减少数据冗余存储
3. 缓存重复的字符串操作
4. 简化逻辑流程
"""

import sys
import argparse
from pathlib import Path
import yaml
import re


def infer_value_type(value_str):
 """推断值的类型并返回适当的Python对象"""
 if not isinstance(value_str, str):
 return value_str

 value_str = value_str.strip()

 # 空值处理
 if value_str == '' or value_str.lower() in ['null', 'nil']:
 return None

 # 布尔值
 if value_str.lower() in ['true', 'false']:
 return value_str.lower() == 'true'

 # 数字（整数）
 if '.' not in value_str and re.match(r'^-?\d+$', value_str):
 try:
 return int(value_str)
 except ValueError:
 pass

 # 数字（浮点数）
 if re.match(r'^-?\d+\.?\d*$', value_str):
 try:
 return float(value_str)
 except ValueError:
 pass

 # 去掉可能的引号
 if len(value_str) >= 2 and (
 (value_str[0] == '"' and value_str[-1] == '"') or
 (value_str[0] == "'" and value_str[-1] == "'")
 ):
 return value_str[1:-1]

 return value_str


def parse_properties_content(content):
 """解析properties文件内容"""
 structure = []
 lines = content.splitlines()

 for i, line in enumerate(lines):
 stripped = line.strip()

 # 注释行
 if stripped.startswith('#') or stripped.startswith('!'):
 structure.append({
 'type': 'comment',
 'content': stripped[1:].strip(),
 'line_num': i + 1
 })
 continue

 # 空行
 if not stripped:
 structure.append({'type': 'empty_line', 'line_num': i + 1})
 continue

 # 属性行
 if '=' in stripped or ':' in stripped:
 separator = '=' if '=' in stripped else ':'
 key, value = stripped.split(separator, 1)
 key = key.strip()
 value = value.strip()

 structure.append({
 'type': 'property',
 'key': key,
 'value': infer_value_type(value),
 'line_num': i + 1
 })
 else:
 print(f"警告：第{i + 1}行格式不正确，跳过: {stripped}")

 return structure


def build_comment_mapping(structure):
 """构建注释到属性的映射关系"""
 comment_mapping = {}
 i = 0

 while i < len(structure):
 if structure[i]['type'] != 'comment':
 i += 1
 continue

 # 收集连续注释块
 comment_start = i
 comments = []
 while i < len(structure) and structure[i]['type'] == 'comment':
 comments.append(structure[i]['content'])
 i += 1
 comment_end = i - 1

 # 判断注释块类型和目标属性
 prev_empty = (comment_start == 0 or
 structure[comment_start - 1]['type'] == 'empty_line')
 next_empty = (comment_end == len(structure) - 1 or
 structure[comment_end + 1]['type'] == 'empty_line')
 next_property = (comment_end < len(structure) - 1 and
 structure[comment_end + 1]['type'] == 'property')

 target_key = None
 position = None

 # 独立注释块（上下都是空行）
 if prev_empty and next_empty:
 # 向上查找属性
 for j in range(comment_start - 1, -1, -1):
 if structure[j]['type'] == 'property':
 target_key = structure[j]['key']
 position = 'below'
 break

 # 向上没找到，向下查找
 if not target_key:
 for j in range(comment_end + 1, len(structure)):
 if structure[j]['type'] == 'property':
 target_key = structure[j]['key']
 position = 'above'
 break

 # 关联注释块（下方是属性）
 elif next_property:
 target_key = structure[comment_end + 1]['key']
 position = 'above'

 # 添加到映射
 if target_key and position:
 if target_key not in comment_mapping:
 comment_mapping[target_key] = []
 comment_mapping[target_key].append({
 'comments': comments,
 'position': position
 })

 return comment_mapping


def dump_yaml_with_structure(structure):
 """生成YAML内容"""
 # 构建注释映射
 comment_mapping = build_comment_mapping(structure)

 # 提取所有属性并按组分类
 properties = [item for item in structure if item['type'] == 'property']
 groups = {} # {top_level_key: [properties]}
 simple_props = [] # 无点号的简单属性

 for prop in properties:
 key = prop['key']
 if '.' in key:
 top_key = key.split('.', 1)[0]
 if top_key not in groups:
 groups[top_key] = []
 groups[top_key].append(prop)
 else:
 simple_props.append(prop)

 # 生成输出
 output_lines = []
 processed_keys = set()

 # 按原始顺序处理
 for item in structure:
 if item['type'] != 'property':
 continue

 key = item['key']
 if key in processed_keys:
 continue

 # 处理分组属性
 if '.' in key:
 top_key = key.split('.', 1)[0]
 if top_key in processed_keys:
 continue

 # 标记该组所有属性为已处理
 for prop in groups[top_key]:
 processed_keys.add(prop['key'])

 # 输出组级上方注释（使用组内第一个属性的注释）
 first_key = groups[top_key][0]['key']
 if first_key in comment_mapping:
 for block in comment_mapping[first_key]:
 if block['position'] == 'above':
 for comment in block['comments']:
 output_lines.append(f"# {comment}")

 # 输出组名
 output_lines.append(f"{top_key}:")

 # 输出组内属性
 nested_path = []
 for idx, prop in enumerate(groups[top_key]):
 prop_key = prop['key']
 value = prop['value']

 # 属性级上方注释（跳过第一个属性的组级注释）
 if prop_key in comment_mapping and not (idx == 0 and prop_key == first_key):
 for block in comment_mapping[prop_key]:
 if block['position'] == 'above':
 for comment in block['comments']:
 output_lines.append(f" # {comment}")

 # 输出属性
 parts = prop_key.split('.')[1:] # 去掉顶层key

 if len(parts) == 1:
 # 二级属性
 yaml_str = yaml.dump({parts[0]: value},
 allow_unicode=True,
 default_flow_style=False,
 sort_keys=False).strip()
 output_lines.append(f" {yaml_str}")
 else:
 # 多级嵌套
 for level, part in enumerate(parts[:-1]):
 path = parts[:level+1]
 if path != nested_path[:len(path)]:
 indent = ' ' * (level + 1)
 output_lines.append(f"{indent}{part}:")
 nested_path = path[:]

 # 最后一级
 final_indent = ' ' * len(parts)
 final_key = parts[-1]
 yaml_str = yaml.dump({final_key: value},
 allow_unicode=True,
 default_flow_style=False,
 sort_keys=False).strip()
 value_part = yaml_str.split(':', 1)[1].strip() if ':' in yaml_str else str(value)
 output_lines.append(f"{final_indent}{final_key}: {value_part}")

 # 属性级下方注释
 if prop_key in comment_mapping:
 for block in comment_mapping[prop_key]:
 if block['position'] == 'below':
 output_lines.append("")
 for comment in block['comments']:
 output_lines.append(f"# {comment}")
 output_lines.append("")

 # 处理简单属性
 else:
 processed_keys.add(key)

 # 上方注释
 if key in comment_mapping:
 for block in comment_mapping[key]:
 if block['position'] == 'above':
 for comment in block['comments']:
 output_lines.append(f"# {comment}")

 # 输出属性
 output_lines.append(f"{key}: '{item['value']}'")

 # 下方注释
 if key in comment_mapping:
 for block in comment_mapping[key]:
 if block['position'] == 'below':
 output_lines.append("")
 for comment in block['comments']:
 output_lines.append(f"# {comment}")
 output_lines.append("")

 # 移除末尾空行
 while output_lines and output_lines[-1] == "":
 output_lines.pop()

 return '\n'.join(output_lines)


def properties_to_yaml(properties_file_path):
 """转换properties文件为YAML格式"""
 try:
 prop_path = Path(properties_file_path)

 if not prop_path.exists():
 print(f"错误：文件不存在 - {properties_file_path}")
 return False

 if not prop_path.is_file():
 print(f"错误：路径不是文件 - {properties_file_path}")
 return False

 with open(prop_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
 content = f.read()

 structure = parse_properties_content(content)
 yaml_content = dump_yaml_with_structure(structure)
 yaml_file_path = prop_path.with_suffix('.yaml')

 with open(yaml_file_path, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:
 f.write(yaml_content)

 print(f"成功转换：{properties_file_path} -> {yaml_file_path}")
 return True

 except Exception as e:
 print(f"转换失败：{properties_file_path}")
 print(f"错误信息：{str(e)}")
 import traceback
 traceback.print_exc()
 return False


def main():
 """主函数：处理命令行参数并执行转换"""
 parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='将properties文件转换为yaml文件')
 parser.add_argument('files', nargs='+', help='要转换的properties文件路径')
 args = parser.parse_args()

 success_count = 0
 fail_count = 0

 print("开始转换properties文件到yaml格式...")
 print("=" * 50)

 for file_path in args.files:
 if properties_to_yaml(file_path):
 success_count += 1
 else:
 fail_count += 1

 print("=" * 50)
 print(f"转换完成！成功：{success_count}个，失败：{fail_count}个")
 return 1 if fail_count > 0 else 0


if __name__ == '__main__':
 sys.exit(main())

🚀 Main Features

✅ Core Functions

  • Multi-file batch conversion - Support simultaneous conversion of multiple configuration files
  • Intelligent type inference - Automatically identify boolean values, numbers, strings and other data types
  • Complete comment preservation - Preserve all original comments and their positional relationships
  • Structure order maintenance - Strictly maintain the key-value pair order of the original file
  • Nested property handling - Intelligent processing of dot-separated hierarchical configurations

🎯 Advanced Features

  • Comment intelligent positioning - Support precise position maintenance of above and below comments
  • Independent comment processing - Intelligent processing of independent comment blocks in files
  • UTF-8 encoding support - Perfect support for Chinese and other multilingual characters
  • Error handling mechanism - Comprehensive error prompts and conversion statistics

📦 Installation Requirements

System Environment

  • Python version: 3.6 or higher
  • Operating system: Windows, Linux, macOS all supported

Dependencies

Need to install PyYAML library:

pip install pyyaml

🛠️ Usage Methods

1. Basic Usage

Convert Single File 

python properties_to_yaml.py config.properties

Convert Multiple Files 

python properties_to_yaml.py app.properties database.properties redis.properties

2. Path Usage

Absolute Path 

python properties_to_yaml.py C:\projects\myapp\config\application.properties

Relative Path 

python properties_to_yaml.py ./config/dev.properties

Current Directory File 

python properties_to_yaml.py application.properties

📝 Conversion Examples

Input File Example (application.properties) 

# ==========================================
# Application Core Configuration
# ==========================================

# Application Basic Information
app.name=MyAwesomeApplication
app.version=2.1.0
app.description=Enterprise Application Platform

# Development Mode Switch
app.debug=true

# Database Connection Configuration
database.host=localhost
database.port=3306
database.username=admin
database.password=secure_password_123

# Connection Pool Configuration
database.pool.max-size=20
database.pool.min-idle=5
database.pool.max-wait=30000

# Other Configuration Items
timeout=30000
max-connections=100

Output File Example (application.yaml) 

# ==========================================
# Application Core Configuration
# ==========================================

# Application Basic Information
app:
 name: MyAwesomeApplication
 version: 2.1.0
 description: Enterprise Application Platform
 # Development Mode Switch
 debug: true

# Database Connection Configuration
database:
 host: localhost
 port: 3306
 username: admin
 password: secure_password_123
 # Connection Pool Configuration
 pool:
 max-size: 20
 min-idle: 5
 max-wait: 30000

# Other Configuration Items
timeout: '30000'
max-connections: '100'

🔧 Function Details

1. Type Inference Mechanism

The tool can intelligently identify and maintain the following data types:

Properties Value Inferred Type YAML Output Description
true/false boolean true/false Boolean values
8080 integer 8080 Integers
30.5 float 30.5 Floating point numbers
hello string hello Strings
"hello world" string hello world Unquoted strings

2. Comment Processing Mechanism

Comment Type Recognition

  • Associated comments: Comments immediately preceding configuration items
  • Independent comments: Comment blocks surrounded by blank lines
  • File header comments: Comments at the beginning of the file

Position Maintenance Strategy 

# This is above comment
config.value=test
# This is below comment

After conversion:

# This is above comment
config:
 value: test
# This is below comment

3. Nested Structure Processing

Dot-separated key names are automatically converted to YAML nested structures:

Properties YAML
database.host=localhost database: {host: localhost}
spring.datasource.url=jdbc:... spring: {datasource: {url: jdbc:...}}

4. Order Maintenance Mechanism

  • Strict order: Completely maintain the key-value pair order in the original properties file
  • Hierarchical order: The hierarchical structure of nested properties also maintains the original order
  • Comment order: The relative position of comments and configuration items is completely maintained

⚙️ Advanced Usage

1. Batch Processing Script 

# Batch convert all properties files in current directory
for file in *.properties; do
 python properties_to_yaml.py "$file"
done

2. Integration into CI/CD Pipeline 

# Using in GitHub Actions
- name: Convert Properties to YAML
 run: |
 python properties_to_yaml.py config/*.properties

3. Import as Module 

from properties_to_yaml import parse_properties_content, dump_yaml_with_structure

# Read and convert
with open('config.properties', 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
 content = f.read()

parsed_data = parse_properties_content(content)
yaml_result = dump_yaml_with_structure(parsed_data)

print(yaml_result)

📊 Output Format Description

Generated File Naming

  • Input: application.properties
  • Output: application.yaml
  • Save location: Same directory as source file

YAML Format Characteristics

  • Uses 2-space indentation
  • Supports UTF-8 encoding
  • Maintains clear hierarchical structure
  • Comments start with #

🚨 Error Handling

Common Errors and Solutions

1. File Not Found 

Error: File does not exist - /path/to/config.properties

Solution: Check if the file path is correct

2. Format Error 

Warning: Line 5 format is incorrect, skipping: invalid=format=line

Solution: Check properties file format, ensure using = or : separator

3. Insufficient Permissions 

Error: Permission denied - config.properties

Solution: Check file read/write permissions

🔍 Troubleshooting

Debugging Tips

  1. View Detailed Output
python properties_to_yaml.py config.properties
  1. Check Generated YAML
cat config.yaml
  1. Validate YAML Syntax
python -c "import yaml; yaml.safe_load(open('config.yaml'))"

📈 Performance Information

Processing Capability

  • Small files (< 100KB): Instant completion
  • Medium files (100KB-1MB): 1-2 seconds
  • Large files (> 1MB): Usually within 5 seconds depending on content complexity

Note: This tool is designed specifically for configuration file conversion and is not suitable for other types of file conversion. It is recommended to backup original files before conversion.

item.title: Golang Learning Journey [Part 13: Concurrency Basics - goroutine + channel]
item.description:
1. Concurrent Programming Basic Concepts

Concurrent programming is an indispensable skill in modern software development. If traditional sequential execution is like a person completing tasks step by step, then concurrency is like simultaneously directing multiple workers to work in parallel. Go language inherently supports concurrency, making concurrent programming simple and efficient.

1.1 What is Concurrency

Let’s understand concurrency through real-life examples:

Real scenario comparison:

  • Sequential execution: One person cooks → washes dishes → cleans house (total 3 hours)
  • Concurrent execution: One person cooks while another washes dishes, third cleans house (total only 1 hour)

Concurrency in programs:

  • Sequential execution: Execute task A → Execute task B → Execute task C
  • Concurrent execution: Execute tasks A, B, C simultaneously

1.2 Concurrency vs Parallelism vs Serial 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "time"
)

// Serial execution example
func serialExecution() {
 fmt.Println("=== Serial Execution ===")
 start := time.Now()

 task1()
 task2()
 task3()

 elapsed := time.Since(start)
 fmt.Printf("Serial execution total time: %v\n\n", elapsed)
}

// Concurrent execution example
func concurrentExecution() {
 fmt.Println("=== Concurrent Execution ===")
 start := time.Now()

 // Start 3 goroutines to execute concurrently
 go task1()
 go task2()
 go task3()

 // Wait some time for goroutines to complete
 time.Sleep(2 * time.Second)

 elapsed := time.Since(start)
 fmt.Printf("Concurrent execution total time: %v\n\n", elapsed)
}

// Simulate time-consuming tasks
func task1() {
 fmt.Println("Task 1 start executing...")
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Println("Task 1 execution completed")
}

func task2() {
 fmt.Println("Task 2 start executing...")
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Println("Task 2 execution completed")
}

func task3() {
 fmt.Println("Task 3 start executing...")
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Println("Task 3 execution completed")
}

func main() {
 serialExecution()
 concurrentExecution()

 // Explain concurrency advantages
 fmt.Println("=== Concurrency Advantages ===")
 fmt.Println("1. Improve program execution efficiency")
 fmt.Println("2. Better utilize multi-core CPUs")
 fmt.Println("3. Improve user experience (faster response)")
 fmt.Println("4. More effective for I/O-intensive tasks")
}

Execution result:

=== Serial Execution ===
Task 1 start executing...
Task 1 execution completed
Task 2 start executing...
Task 2 execution completed
Task 3 start executing...
Task 3 execution completed
Serial execution total time: 3.004s

=== Concurrent Execution ===
Task 1 start executing...
Task 2 start executing...
Task 3 start executing...
Task 1 execution completed
Task 2 execution completed
Task 3 execution completed
Concurrent execution total time: 1.001s

=== Concurrency Advantages ===
1. Improve program execution efficiency
2. Better utilize multi-core CPUs
3. Improve user experience (faster response)
4. More effective for I/O-intensive tasks

1.3 Core Components of Go Concurrency

Go concurrent programming mainly relies on two core concepts:

  1. Goroutine: Lightweight threads managed by Go runtime
  2. Channel: Pipes for communication and synchronization between goroutines
package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "runtime"
 "time"
)

func demonstrateGoroutineBasics() {
 fmt.Println("=== Goroutine Basic Demonstration ===")

 // Check current goroutine count
 fmt.Printf("Initial goroutine count: %d\n", runtime.NumGoroutine())

 // Start multiple goroutines
 for i := 1; i <= 5; i++ {
 go func(id int) {
 fmt.Printf("Goroutine %d start executing\n", id)
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(id) * 100 * time.Millisecond)
 fmt.Printf("Goroutine %d execution completed\n", id)
 }(i)
 }

 fmt.Printf("Goroutine count after startup: %d\n", runtime.NumGoroutine())

 // Wait for goroutines to complete
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Printf("Final goroutine count: %d\n", runtime.NumGoroutine())
}

func demonstrateChannelBasics() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Channel Basic Demonstration ===")

 // Create channel
 ch := make(chan string)

 // Start producer goroutine
 go func() {
 fmt.Println("Producer: Preparing to send data...")
 ch <- "Hello from goroutine!" // Send data to channel
 fmt.Println("Producer: Data sending completed")
 }()

 // Main goroutine as consumer
 fmt.Println("Main program: Waiting to receive data...")
 message := <-ch // Receive data from channel
 fmt.Printf("Main program: Received data: %s\n", message)
}

func main() {
 demonstrateGoroutineBasics()
 demonstrateChannelBasics()
}

Execution result:

=== Goroutine Basic Demonstration ===
Initial goroutine count: 1
Goroutine count after startup: 6
Goroutine 5 start executing
Goroutine 1 start executing
Goroutine 2 start executing
Goroutine 3 start executing
Goroutine 4 start executing
Goroutine 1 execution completed
Goroutine 2 execution completed
Goroutine 3 execution completed
Goroutine 4 execution completed
Goroutine 5 execution completed
Final goroutine count: 1

=== Channel Basic Demonstration ===
Main program: Waiting to receive data...
Producer: Preparing to send data...
Producer: Data sending completed
Main program: Received data: Hello from goroutine!

2. Goroutine Detailed Explanation

2.1 Goroutine Creation and Management 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "runtime"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

// WaitGroup to wait for a group of goroutines to complete
func demonstrateWaitGroup() {
 fmt.Println("=== Using WaitGroup to Wait for Goroutine Completion ===")

 var wg sync.WaitGroup
 tasks := []string{"Task A", "Task B", "Task C", "Task D"}

 // Add count for each task
 wg.Add(len(tasks))

 for i, task := range tasks {
 go func(id int, name string) {
 defer wg.Done() // Decrease count when task completes
 fmt.Printf("Start executing %s (goroutine %d)\n", name, id)
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(id+1) * 500 * time.Millisecond)
 fmt.Printf("%s execution completed (goroutine %d)\n", name, id)
 }(i, task)
 }

 fmt.Println("Waiting for all tasks to complete...")
 wg.Wait() // Wait for all goroutines to complete
 fmt.Println("All tasks completed!")
}

// Goroutines with parameters
func demonstrateGoroutineParameters() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Goroutines with Parameters ===")

 // Method 1: Use anonymous function to capture parameters
 for i := 1; i <= 3; i++ {
 value := i // Important: Create local variable copy
 go func() {
 fmt.Printf("Method 1 - Value: %d\n", value)
 }()
 }

 // Method 2: Pass through function parameters
 for i := 1; i <= 3; i++ {
 go func(val int) {
 fmt.Printf("Method 2 - Value: %d\n", val)
 }(i)
 }

 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
}

// Goroutine lifecycle management
func demonstrateLifecycle() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Goroutine Lifecycle ===")

 // Create a long-running goroutine
 stop := make(chan bool)

 go func() {
 for {
 select {
 case <-stop:
 fmt.Println("Goroutine received stop signal, exiting...")
 return
 default:
 fmt.Println("Goroutine working...")
 time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
 }
 }
 }()

 // Let goroutine run for a while
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)

 // Send stop signal
 fmt.Println("Sending stop signal...")
 stop <- true

 // Wait for confirmation of stopping
 time.Sleep(500 * time.Millisecond)
 fmt.Println("Main program ended")
}

func main() {
 demonstrateWaitGroup()
 demonstrateGoroutineParameters()
 demonstrateLifecycle()

 // Check system information
 fmt.Println("\n=== System Information ===")
 fmt.Printf("CPU cores: %d\n", runtime.NumCPU())
 fmt.Printf("Current goroutine count: %d\n", runtime.NumGoroutine())
}

2.2 Goroutine Scheduling Mechanism 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "runtime"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

func demonstrateScheduler() {
 fmt.Println("=== Goroutine Scheduling Demonstration ===")

 var wg sync.WaitGroup
 wg.Add(2)

 // CPU-intensive task
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 fmt.Println("CPU-intensive task start")
 count := 0
 for i := 0; i < 1000000; i++ {
 count += i
 }
 fmt.Printf("CPU-intensive task completed, count=%d\n", count)
 }()

 // I/O-intensive task
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 fmt.Println("I/O-intensive task start")
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond) // Simulate I/O wait
 fmt.Println("I/O-intensive task completed")
 }()

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Println("All tasks completed")
}

func demonstratePreemption() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Preemptive Scheduling Demonstration ===")

 // Create multiple short tasks to observe scheduling
 var wg sync.WaitGroup
 taskCount := 10

 wg.Add(taskCount)
 for i := 0; i < taskCount; i++ {
 go func(id int) {
 defer wg.Done()
 fmt.Printf("Task %d start executing\n", id)

 // Simulate some work
 for j := 0; j < 100000; j++ {
 _ = j * j // CPU calculation
 }

 fmt.Printf("Task %d execution completed\n", id)
 }(i)
 }

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Println("All short tasks completed")
}

func main() {
 demonstrateScheduler()
 demonstratePreemption()

 // Display scheduler information
 fmt.Println("\n=== Scheduler Information ===")
 fmt.Printf("GOMAXPROCS: %d\n", runtime.GOMAXPROCS(0))
 fmt.Printf("NumCPU: %d\n", runtime.NumCPU())

 // Set GOMAXPROCS
 old := runtime.GOMAXPROCS(2)
 fmt.Printf("Old GOMAXPROCS: %d, New GOMAXPROCS: %d\n", old, runtime.GOMAXPROCS(0))
}

3. Channel Detailed Explanation

3.1 Channel Basic Operations 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "time"
)

// Basic channel operations
func basicChannelOperations() {
 fmt.Println("=== Basic Channel Operations ===")

 // 1. Create channel
 ch := make(chan int)

 // 2. Send data
 go func() {
 fmt.Println("Sending data: 100")
 ch <- 100
 fmt.Println("Sending data: 200")
 ch <- 200
 }()

 // 3. Receive data
 value1 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", value1)

 value2 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", value2)
}

// Buffered channel
func bufferedChannel() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Buffered Channel ===")

 // Create buffered channel (buffer size 2)
 ch := make(chan string, 2)

 // Can send continuously without blocking (when buffer is not full)
 ch <- "Message 1"
 fmt.Println("Sent message 1")

 ch <- "Message 2"
 fmt.Println("Sent message 2")

 // Buffer is full, this will block
 fmt.Println("Preparing to send message 3...")
 go func() {
 ch <- "Message 3"
 fmt.Println("Message 3 sending completed")
 }()

 // Receive data
 msg1 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg1)

 msg2 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg2)

 msg3 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg3)
}

// Unidirectional channel
func directionalChannel() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Unidirectional Channel ===")

 ch := make(chan int)

 // Sender: can only send data
 go sendOnly(ch)

 // Receiver: can only receive data
 receiveOnly(ch)
}

func sendOnly(ch chan<- int) {
 fmt.Println("Sender: Sending data")
 ch <- 42
 fmt.Println("Sender: Sending completed")
}

func receiveOnly(ch <-chan int) {
 fmt.Println("Receiver: Waiting for data")
 value := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Receiver: Received %d\n", value)
}

// Channel closing and range
func channelCloseAndRange() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Channel Closing and Range ===")

 ch := make(chan int, 3)

 // Send data
 go func() {
 for i := 1; i <= 5; i++ {
 ch <- i
 fmt.Printf("Sent: %d\n", i)
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
 }
 close(ch) // Close channel
 fmt.Println("Channel closed")
 }()

 // Use range to receive all data
 fmt.Println("Start receiving data...")
 for value := range ch {
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", value)
 }
 fmt.Println("Receiving completed")
}

func main() {
 basicChannelOperations()
 bufferedChannel()
 directionalChannel()
 channelCloseAndRange()
}

3.2 Select Statement 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "time"
)

// Basic select usage
func basicSelect() {
 fmt.Println("=== Basic Select Usage ===")

 ch1 := make(chan string)
 ch2 := make(chan string)

 go func() {
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
 ch1 <- "Message from channel 1"
 }()

 go func() {
 time.Sleep(200 * time.Millisecond)
 ch2 <- "Message from channel 2"
 }()

 // select waits for multiple channel operations
 for i := 0; i < 2; i++ {
 select {
 case msg1 := <-ch1:
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg1)
 case msg2 := <-ch2:
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg2)
 }
 }
}

// Select with default branch
func selectWithDefault() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Select with Default Branch ===")

 ch := make(chan int)

 // Non-blocking select
 select {
 case value := <-ch:
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", value)
 default:
 fmt.Println("No data to receive, executing default branch")
 }

 // Send data
 go func() {
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
 ch <- 42
 }()

 // Wait and receive
 select {
 case value := <-ch:
 fmt.Printf("Now received: %d\n", value)
 case <-time.After(200 * time.Millisecond):
 fmt.Println("Timed out")
 }
}

// Timeout control
func timeoutControl() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Timeout Control ===")

 ch := make(chan string)

 // Simulate potentially timeout operation
 go func() {
 // Randomly decide whether to timeout
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(150) * time.Millisecond)
 ch <- "Operation completed"
 }()

 // Use select to implement timeout
 select {
 case result := <-ch:
 fmt.Printf("Success: %s\n", result)
 case <-time.After(100 * time.Millisecond):
 fmt.Println("Operation timed out")
 }
}

// Multiplexing
func multiplexing() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Multiplexing ===")

 // Create multiple channels
 channels := make([]chan int, 3)
 for i := range channels {
 channels[i] = make(chan int)
 }

 // Start multiple producers
 for i, ch := range channels {
 go func(id int, c chan int) {
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(id*100) * time.Millisecond)
 c <- id * 10
 }(i, ch)
 }

 // Use select for multiplexing reception
 received := 0
 for received < len(channels) {
 select {
 case val := <-channels[0]:
 fmt.Printf("Received from channel 0: %d\n", val)
 received++
 case val := <-channels[1]:
 fmt.Printf("Received from channel 1: %d\n", val)
 received++
 case val := <-channels[2]:
 fmt.Printf("Received from channel 2: %d\n", val)
 received++
 }
 }
}

func main() {
 basicSelect()
 selectWithDefault()
 timeoutControl()
 multiplexing()
}

Execution result:

=== Basic Select Usage ===
Received: Message from channel 1
Received: Message from channel 2

=== Select with Default Branch ===
No data to receive, executing default branch
Now received: 42

=== Timeout Control ===

=== Multiplexing ===

Received from channel 1: 10
Received from channel 2: 20

4. Practical Application Scenarios

4.1 Worker Pool Pattern 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

// Work task structure
type Job struct {
 ID int
 Data string
}

// Work result structure
type Result struct {
 JobID int
 Value string
 Error error
}

// Worker Pool implementation
type WorkerPool struct {
 workers int
 jobQueue chan Job
 resultChan chan Result
 wg sync.WaitGroup
}

func NewWorkerPool(workers int) *WorkerPool {
 return &WorkerPool{
 workers: workers,
 jobQueue: make(chan Job, 100),
 resultChan: make(chan Result, 100),
 }
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) Start() {
 for i := 0; i < wp.workers; i++ {
 wp.wg.Add(1)
 go wp.worker(i)
 }
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) worker(id int) {
 defer wp.wg.Done()
 fmt.Printf("Worker %d started\n", id)

 for job := range wp.jobQueue {
 fmt.Printf("Worker %d processing task %d\n", id, job.ID)

 // Simulate work processing
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)

 // Generate result
 result := Result{
 JobID: job.ID,
 Value: fmt.Sprintf("Processing result-%s", job.Data),
 }

 wp.resultChan <- result
 }

 fmt.Printf("Worker %d stopped\n", id)
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) Submit(job Job) {
 wp.jobQueue <- job
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) GetResult() <-chan Result {
 return wp.resultChan
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) Stop() {
 close(wp.jobQueue)
 wp.wg.Wait()
 close(wp.resultChan)
}

func demonstrateWorkerPool() {
 fmt.Println("=== Worker Pool Pattern Demonstration ===")

 // Create worker pool
 pool := NewWorkerPool(3)
 pool.Start()

 // Submit tasks
 jobs := []Job{
 {ID: 1, Data: "Task 1 data"},
 {ID: 2, Data: "Task 2 data"},
 {ID: 3, Data: "Task 3 data"},
 {ID: 4, Data: "Task 4 data"},
 {ID: 5, Data: "Task 5 data"},
 }

 // Submit all tasks
 for _, job := range jobs {
 pool.Submit(job)
 }

 // Collect results
 results := make([]Result, 0, len(jobs))
 for i := 0; i < len(jobs); i++ {
 result := <-pool.GetResult()
 results = append(results, result)
 fmt.Printf("Received result: Task %d -> %s\n", result.JobID, result.Value)
 }

 // Stop pool
 pool.Stop()
 fmt.Println("Worker Pool stopped")
}

func main() {
 demonstrateWorkerPool()
}

Execution result:

=== Worker Pool Pattern Demonstration ===
Worker 2 started
Worker 0 started
Worker 1 started
Worker 0 processing task 1
Worker 2 processing task 2
Worker 1 processing task 3
Received result: Task 1 -> Processing result-Task 1 data
Worker 0 processing task 4
Received result: Task 2 -> Processing result-Task 2 data
Worker 2 processing task 5
Received result: Task 3 -> Processing result-Task 3 data
Received result: Task 4 -> Processing result-Task 4 data
Received result: Task 5 -> Processing result-Task 5 data
Worker 0 stopped
Worker 1 stopped
Worker 2 stopped
Worker Pool stopped

4.2 Producer-Consumer Pattern 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "math/rand"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

type Item struct {
 ID int
 Value string
}

// Producer
func producer(id int, items chan<- Item, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
 defer wg.Done()

 for i := 1; i <= 3; i++ {
 item := Item{
 ID: id*100 + i,
 Value: fmt.Sprintf("Producer %d-Product %d", id, i),
 }

 fmt.Printf("Producer %d produces: %+v\n", id, item)
 items <- item
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(rand.Intn(300)) * time.Millisecond)
 }

 fmt.Printf("Producer %d completed\n", id)
}

// Consumer
func consumer(id int, items <-chan Item, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
 defer wg.Done()

 for item := range items {
 fmt.Printf("Consumer %d consumes: %+v\n", id, item)
 // Simulate processing time
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(rand.Intn(200)) * time.Millisecond)
 }

 fmt.Printf("Consumer %d exited\n", id)
}

func demonstrateProducerConsumer() {
 fmt.Println("=== Producer-Consumer Pattern ===")

 items := make(chan Item, 10) // Buffered channel
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 // Start producers
 producers := 2
 consumers := 3

 for i := 1; i <= producers; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go producer(i, items, &wg)
 }

 // Start consumers
 for i := 1; i <= consumers; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go consumer(i, items, &wg)
 }

 // Wait for producers to complete
 wg.Wait()

 // Close channel, let consumers know no more data
 close(items)

 // Give consumers some time to process remaining data
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Println("All production and consumption completed")
}

func main() {
 rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())
 demonstrateProducerConsumer()
}

Execution result:

=== Producer-Consumer Pattern ===
Producer 1 produces: {ID:101 Value:Producer 1-Product 1}
Producer 2 produces: {ID:201 Value:Producer 2-Product 1}
Consumer 1 consumes: {ID:101 Value:Producer 1-Product 1}
Producer 1 produces: {ID:102 Value:Producer 1-Product 2}
Consumer 2 consumes: {ID:201 Value:Producer 2-Product 1}
Producer 2 produces: {ID:202 Value:Producer 2-Product 2}
Consumer 3 consumes: {ID:102 Value:Producer 1-Product 2}
Producer 1 produces: {ID:103 Value:Producer 1-Product 3}
Consumer 1 consumes: {ID:202 Value:Producer 2-Product 2}
Producer 2 produces: {ID:203 Value:Producer 2-Product 3}
Consumer 2 consumes: {ID:103 Value:Producer 1-Product 3}
Producer 1 completed
Consumer 3 consumes: {ID:203 Value:Producer 2-Product 3}
Producer 2 completed
Consumer 1 exited
Consumer 2 exited
Consumer 3 exited
All production and consumption completed

4.3 Fan-in Fan-out Pattern 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

// Fan-out: One input, multiple outputs
func fanOut(input <-chan int, outputs []chan<- int) {
 for value := range input {
 // Send data to all output channels
 for _, output := range outputs {
 output <- value
 }
 }

 // Close all output channels
 for _, output := range outputs {
 close(output)
 }
}

// Fan-in: Multiple inputs, one output
func fanIn(inputs []<-chan int, output chan<- int) {
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 // Start a goroutine for each input channel
 for _, input := range inputs {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func(ch <-chan int) {
 defer wg.Done()
 for value := range ch {
 output <- value
 }
 }(input)
 }

 // Wait for all inputs to complete processing
 go func() {
 wg.Wait()
 close(output)
 }()
}

func demonstrateFanInOut() {
 fmt.Println("=== Fan-in Fan-out Pattern ===")

 // Create input channel
 input := make(chan int, 5)

 // Create multiple output channels
 outputs := make([]chan int, 3)
 for i := range outputs {
 outputs[i] = make(chan int, 5)
 }

 // Start fan-out
 go fanOut(input, outputs)

 // Create fan-in inputs (from fan-out outputs)
 fanInInput := make([]<-chan int, len(outputs))
 for i, output := range outputs {
 fanInInput[i] = output
 }

 // Create final output
 finalOutput := make(chan int, 15)

 // Start fan-in
 go fanIn(fanInInput, finalOutput)

 // Send data to input
 go func() {
 for i := 1; i <= 5; i++ {
 input <- i
 fmt.Printf("Sending data: %d\n", i)
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
 }
 close(input)
 }()

 // Receive final results
 fmt.Println("Receiving processed results:")
 for result := range finalOutput {
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", result)
 }

 fmt.Println("Fan-in fan-out processing completed")
}

func main() {
 demonstrateFanInOut()
}

5. Concurrency Safety and Best Practices

5.1 Race Conditions and Mutex 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

// Unsafe concurrent counter (will cause race condition)
func unsafeCounter() {
 fmt.Println("=== Unsafe Concurrent Counter ===")

 counter := 0
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 // Start multiple goroutines to increment counter simultaneously
 for i := 0; i < 1000; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 counter++ // Race condition!
 }()
 }

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Printf("Expected value: 1000, Actual value: %d\n", counter)
}

// Safe concurrent counter (using mutex)
func safeCounter() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Safe Concurrent Counter ===")

 var counter int
 var mutex sync.Mutex
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 for i := 0; i < 1000; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 mutex.Lock()
 counter++ // Critical section
 mutex.Unlock()
 }()
 }

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Printf("Expected value: 1000, Actual value: %d\n", counter)
}

// Using atomic operations
func atomicCounter() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Atomic Operation Counter ===")

 var counter int64
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 for i := 0; i < 1000; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 // Atomic increment operation
 // atomic.AddInt64(&counter, 1)
 counter++ // Simplified example, should use atomic package actually
 }()
 }

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Printf("Expected value: 1000, Actual value: %d\n", counter)
}

// Read-write lock example
func readWriteLockExample() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Read-Write Lock Example ===")

 var data = make(map[string]string)
 var rwMutex sync.RWMutex
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 // Write operation
 wg.Add(1)
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 rwMutex.Lock()
 fmt.Println("Write operation: Acquired write lock")
 data["key1"] = "value1"
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond) // Simulate write operation time cost
 fmt.Println("Write operation: Released write lock")
 rwMutex.Unlock()
 }()

 // Read operations
 for i := 0; i < 3; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func(id int) {
 defer wg.Done()
 rwMutex.RLock()
 fmt.Printf("Read operation %d: Acquired read lock\n", id)
 value := data["key1"]
 time.Sleep(50 * time.Millisecond) // Simulate read operation time cost
 fmt.Printf("Read operation %d: Read value=%s, Released read lock\n", id, value)
 rwMutex.RUnlock()
 }(i)
 }

 wg.Wait()
}

func main() {
 unsafeCounter()
 safeCounter()
 atomicCounter()
 readWriteLockExample()
}

Execution result:

=== Unsafe Concurrent Counter ===
Expected value: 1000, Actual value: 947

=== Safe Concurrent Counter ===
Expected value: 1000, Actual value: 1000
